get.description: DescriptionThis operation returns the current data retrieval policy for the account and region specified in thettttGET request. For more information about data retrieval policies, seetttAmazon Glacier Data Retrieval Policies.RequestsTo return the current data retrieval policy, send an HTTP GET request to the data retrievaltttpolicy URI as shown in the following syntax example.

parameters.name: BytesPerHour
parameters.description: The maximum number of bytes that can be retrieved in an hour.

parameters.name: Rules
parameters.description: The policy rule. Although this is a list type, currently there will be only one rule, which contains attttttttStrategy field and optionally a BytesPerHour field.

parameters.name: Strategy
parameters.description: The type of data retrieval policy.

put.description: DescriptionThis operation sets and then enacts a data retrieval policy in the region specified in the PUT request. You can set onetttpolicy per region for an AWS account. The policy is enacted within a few minutes of atttsuccessful PUT operation.  The set policy operation does not affect retrieval jobs that were in progress before the policy wastttenacted. For more information about data retrieval policies, see Amazon Glacier Data Retrieval Policies. Requests

parameters.name: BytesPerHour
parameters.description: The maximum number of bytes that can be retrieved in an hour.

parameters.name: Rules
parameters.description: The policy rule. Although this is a list type, currently there must be only onettttttttrule, which contains a Strategy field and optionally a BytesPerHour field.

parameters.name: Strategy
parameters.description: The type of data retrieval policy to set.

post.description: Purchase Provisioned Capacity (POST provisioned-capacity)This operation purchases a provisioned capacity unit for an AWS account.RequestsTo purchase provisioned capacity unit for an AWS account send an HTTP POST         request to the provisioned-capacity URI.

get.description: DescriptionThis operation lists all vaults owned by the calling user’s account. The list returned intttthe response is ASCII-sorted by vault name. By default, this operation returns up to 1,000 items per request. If there are more vaultstttto list, the marker field in the response body contains the vault AmazontttResource Name (ARN) at which to continue the list with a new List Vaults request;tttotherwise, the marker field is null. In your next List Vaultstttrequest you set the marker parameter to the value Amazon Glacier returned in thetttresponses to your previous List Vaults request. You can also limit the number of vaultstttreturned in the response by specifying the limit parameter in the request. RequestsTo get a list of vaults, you send a GET request to thettttvaults resource.

parameters.name: CreationDate
parameters.description: The date the vault was created, in Coordinated Universal Time (UTC).

parameters.name: LastInventoryDate
parameters.description: The date of the last vault inventory, in Coordinated Universal Time (UTC). This fieldttttttttcan be null if an inventory has not yet run on the vault, forttttttttexample, if you just created the vault. For information aboutttttttttinitiating an inventory for a vault, see Initiate Job (POST jobs).

parameters.name: Marker
parameters.description: The vaultARN that represents where to continue pagination of the results.ttttttttYou use the marker in another List Vaults request tottttttttobtain more vaults in the list. If there are no more vaults, thisttttttttvalue is null.

parameters.name: NumberOfArchives
parameters.description: The number of archives in the vault as of the last inventory date.

parameters.name: SizeInBytes
parameters.description: The total size, in bytes, of all the archives in the vault including any per-archivettttttttoverhead, as of the last inventory date.

parameters.name: VaultARN
parameters.description: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the vault.

parameters.name: VaultList
parameters.description: An array of objects, with each object providing a description of a vault.

parameters.name: VaultName
parameters.description: The vault name.

delete.description: DescriptionThis operation deletes a vault. Amazon Glacier will delete a vault only if there are no archivestttin the vault as per the last inventory and there have been no writes to the vault sincetttthe last inventory. If either of these conditions is not satisfied, the vault deletiontttfails (that is, the vault is not removed) and Amazon Glacier returns an error. You can use the Describe Vault (GET vault)tttoperation that provides vault information, including the number of archives in the vault;ttthowever, the information is based on the vault inventory Amazon Glacier lasttttgenerated.This operation is idempotent.NoteWhen you delete a vault, the vault access policy attached to the vault is also deleted. ttttFor more information about vault access policies, see Amazon Glacier Access Control with Vault Access Policies.RequestsTo delete a vault, send a DELETE request to the vault resource URI.

get.description: DescriptionThis operation returns information about a vault, including the vault Amazon Resource Namettt(ARN), the date the vault was created, the number of archives contained within thetttvault, and the total size of all the archives in the vault. The number of archives andttttheir total size are as of the last vault inventory Amazon Glacier generated (see Working with Vaults in Amazon Glacier). Amazon Glaciertttgenerates vault inventories approximately daily. This means that if you add or remove antttarchive from a vault, and then immediately send a Describe Vault request, the responsetttmight not reflect the changes.  RequestsTo get information about a vault, send a GET request to the URI of the specifictttvault resource.

parameters.name: CreationDate
parameters.description: The UTC date when the vault was created.

parameters.name: LastInventoryDate
parameters.description: The UTC date when Amazon Glacier completed the last vault inventory. For information abouttttttttinitiating an inventory for a vault, see Initiate Job (POST jobs).

parameters.name: NumberOfArchives
parameters.description: The number of archives in the vault as per the last vault inventory. This field willtttttttreturn null if an inventory has not yet run on the vault, for example,tttttttif you just created the vault.

parameters.name: SizeInBytes
parameters.description: The total size in bytes of the archives in the vault including any per-archive overhead,tttttttas of the last inventory date. This field will return nulltttttttif an inventory has not yet run on the vault, for example, if you justtttttttcreated the vault.

parameters.name: VaultARN
parameters.description: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the vault.

parameters.name: VaultName
parameters.description: The vault name that was specified at creation time. The vault name is also included intttttttthe vaults ARN.

put.description: DescriptionThis operation creates a new vault with the specified name.  The name of the vault must betttunique within a region for an AWS account. You can create up to 1,000 vaults pertttaccount. For information on creating more vaults, go to the Amazon Glacier product detailtttpage.You must use the following guidelines when naming a vault. ttt Names can be between 1 and 255 characters long. Allowed characters are a–z, A–Z, 0–9, _ (underscore), - (hyphen),ttttttand . (period).ttThis operation is idempotent, you can send the same request multiple times and it has notttfurther effect after the first time Amazon Glacier creates the specified vault.Requests

delete.description: DescriptionThis operation deletes the access policy associated with the specified vault. Thetttoperation is eventually consistent—that is, it might take some time for Amazon Glacier totttcompletely remove the access policy, and you might still see the effect of the policytttfor a short time after you send the delete request. This operation is idempotent. You can invoke delete multiple times, even if there istttno policy associated with the vault. For more information about vault access policies,tttsee Amazon Glacier Access Control with Vault Access Policies.RequestsTo delete the current vault access policy, send an HTTP DELETE request totttthe URI of the vaults access-policy subresource.

get.description: DescriptionThis operation retrieves the access-policy subresource set on thetttvault—for more information on setting this subresource, see Set Vault Access Policy (PUT access-policy). Iftttthere is no access policy set on the vault, the operation returns a 404 Notttttfound error. For more information about vault access policies, see Amazon Glacier Access Control with Vault Access Policies.RequestsTo return the current vault access policy, send an HTTP GET request totttthe URI of the vaults access-policy subresource.

parameters.name: Policy
parameters.description: The vault access policy as a JSON string, which uses \ as an escape character.

put.description: DescriptionThis operation configures an access policy for a vault and will overwrite an existingtttpolicy. To configure a vault access policy, send a PUT request to thettttaccess-policy subresource of the vault. You can set one access policy per vaulttttand the policy can be up to 20 KB in size. For more information about vault accesstttpolicies, see Amazon Glacier Access Control with Vault Access Policies. Requests

parameters.name: Policy
parameters.description: The vault access policy as a JSON string, which uses \ as an escape character.

post.description: DescriptionThis operation adds an archive to a vault. For a successful upload, your data is durablytttpersisted. In response, Amazon Glacier returns the archive ID in thettttx-amz-archive-id header of the response. You should save the archive IDtttreturned so that you can access the archive later. You must provide a SHA256 tree hash of the data you are uploading. For information abouttttcomputing a SHA256 tree hash, see Computing Checksums. When uploading an archive, you can optionally specify an archive description of up to 1,024tttprintable ASCII characters. Amazon Glacier returns the archive description when youttteither retrieve the archive or get the vault inventory. Amazon Glacier does not interpret thetttdescription in any way. An archive description does not need to be unique. You cannottttuse the description to retrieve or sort the archive list. Except for the optional archive description, Amazon Glacier does not support anytttadditional metadata for the archives. The archive ID is an opaque sequence of characterstttfrom which you cannot infer any meaning about the archive. So you might maintaintttmetadata about the archives on the client-side. For more information, see tttWorking with Archives in Amazon Glacier.Archives are immutable. After you upload an archive, you cannot edit the archive or itstttdescription. RequestsTo upload an archive, you use the HTTP POST method and scope the request to thettttarchives subresource of the vault in which you want to save thetttarchive. The request must include the archive payload size, checksum (SHA256 tree hash),tttand can optionally include a description of the archive.

delete.description: DescriptionThis operation deletes an archive from a vault. You can delete one archive at a time from a vault. tttTo delete the archive you must provide its archive ID in the delete request. tttYou can get the archive ID by downloading the vault inventory for the vault that contains the archive. tttFor more information about downloading the vault inventory, tttsee Downloading a Vault Inventory in Amazon Glacier.After you delete an archive, you might stilltttbe able to make a successful request to initiate a job to retrieve the deleted archive,tttbut the archive retrieval job will fail. Archive retrievals that are in progress for an archive ID when you delete thetttarchive might or might not succeed according to the following scenarios:tttIf the archive retrieval job is actively preparing the data for download when Amazon Glacierttttttreceives the delete archive request, the archival retrievaltoperation might fail. If the archive retrieval job has successfully prepared the archive for download whenttttttAmazon Glacier receives the delete archive request, you will be able tottttttdownload the output. ttFor more information about archive retrieval, see tttDownloading an Archive in Amazon Glacier. This operation is idempotent. Attemptingtttto delete an already-deleted archive does not result in an error. RequestsTo delete an archive you send a DELETE request to the archive resourcetttURI.

get.description: DescriptionThis operation lists jobs for a vault including jobs that are in-progress and jobs that havetttrecently finished. tttNoteAmazon Glacier retains recently completed jobs for a period before deleting them; however,tttttit eventually removes completed jobs. The output of completed jobs can betttttretrieved. Retaining completed jobs for a period of time after they havetttttcompleted enables you to get a job output in the event you miss the jobtttttcompletion notification or your first attempt to download it fails. For example,tttttsuppose you start an archive retrieval job to download an archive. After the jobtttttcompletes, you start to download the archive but encounter a network error. Intttttthis scenario, you can retry and download the archive while the job exists. ttTo retrieve an archive or retrieve a vault inventory from Amazon Glacier, you first initiatettta job, and after the job completes, you download the data. For an archive retrieval, thetttoutput is the archive data. For an inventory retrieval, it is the inventory list.tttThe List Job operation returns a list of these jobs sorted by job initiationttttime.The List Jobs operation supports pagination. You should always check the responsettttMarker field. If there are no more jobs to list, thettttMarker field is set to null. If there are more jobs totttlist, the Marker field is set to a non-null value, which you can use totttcontinue the pagination of the list. To return a list of jobs that begins at a specifictttjob, set the marker request parameter to the Marker value fortttthat job that you obtained from a previous List Jobs request.You can set a maximum limit for the number of jobs returned in the response by specifyingtttthe limit parameter in the request. The default limit is 1000. The numbertttof jobs returned might be fewer than the limit but the number of returned jobs nevertttexceeds the limit.Additionally, you can filter the jobs list returned by specifying the optionaltttstatuscode parameter or completed parameter, or both. Usingtttthe statuscode parameter, you can specify to return only jobs that matchttteither the InProgress, Succeeded, or Failed status.tttUsing the completed parameter, you can specify to return only jobs that weretttcompleted (true) or jobs that were not completedttt(false).Requests

parameters.name: Action
parameters.description: For archive retrieval jobs, this value is ArchiveRetrieval. For inventorytttttttretrieval jobs, this value is InventoryRetrieval.

parameters.name: ArchiveId
parameters.description: The ID of the archive that was requested in an archive retrieval. Thistttttttfield only appears for archive retrieval job descriptions.

parameters.name: ArchiveSHA256TreeHash
parameters.description: The SHA256 tree hash of the entire archive for an archive retrieval. For inventorytttttttretrieval jobs, this field is null.

parameters.name: ArchiveSizeInBytes
parameters.description: The size of the archive for which the archive retrieval job requesttttttttwas initiated.

parameters.name: Completed
parameters.description: true if the job is completed; false otherwise.

parameters.name: CompletionDate
parameters.description: The Universal Coordinated Time (UTC) date when the job completed.

parameters.name: CreationDate
parameters.description: The Universal Coordinated Time (UTC) date the job started.

parameters.name: EndDate
parameters.description: The end of the date range in UTC for vault inventory retrieval that includes tttttttarchives created before this date.

parameters.name: Format
parameters.description: The output format for the vault inventory list, which is set by the  tttttttInitiate Job (POST jobs) request  tttttttwhen initiating a job to retrieve a vault inventory.

parameters.name: InventorySizeInBytes
parameters.description: The size of the inventory associated with an inventory retrieval job request. This fieldtttttttappears only for inventory retrieval job descriptions.

parameters.name: JobDescription
parameters.description: A description of the job.

parameters.name: JobId
parameters.description: The ID that represents the job in Amazon Glacier.

parameters.name: JobList
parameters.description: An array of job objects. Each job object contains a set of name-value pairs describingtttttttthe job.

parameters.name: Limit
parameters.description: Specifies the maximum number of inventory items returned per vault inventory retrievaltttttttrequest. This limit is set when initiating the job with an Initiate Job (POST jobs) request.

parameters.name: Marker
parameters.description: An opaque string that represents where to continue pagination of the results. You usetttttttthe marker value in a new List Jobs request to obtain moretttttttjobs in the list. If there are no more jobs to list, this value isttttttttnull.

parameters.name: Marker (InventoryRetrievalParameters)
parameters.description: An opaque string that represents where to continue pagination of the vault inventorytttttttretrieval results. You use the marker in a new Initiate Jobttttttt request to obtain additional inventory items. If there are notttttttmore inventory items, this value is null. For informationtttttttabout using the marker, see Range Inventory Retrieval.

parameters.name: RetrievalByteRange
parameters.description: The retrieved byte range for archive retrieval jobs in the formttttttttStartByteValue-EndByteValuetttttttIf no range was specified in the archive retrieval, then the wholetttttttarchive is retrieved and StartByteValue equals 0tttttttand EndByteValue equals the size of the archivetttttttminus 1. For inventory retrieval jobs this field is null.

parameters.name: SHA256TreeHash
parameters.description: The SHA256 tree hash value for the requested range of an archive. If the Initiate Job (POST jobs) request for an archivetttttttspecified a tree-hash aligned range, then this field returns a value.tttttttFor more information about tree hash aligned ranges for archive rangetttttttretrievals, see Receiving Checksums When Downloading Data.

parameters.name: SNSTopic
parameters.description: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) that represents an Amazon SNS topic where notification oftttttttjob completion or failure is sent, if notification was configured in thetttttttjob initiation (Initiate Job (POST jobs)).

parameters.name: StartDate
parameters.description: The start of the date range in UTC for vault inventory retrieval that includes archivestttttttcreated on or after this date.

parameters.name: StatusCode
parameters.description: The job status code. The values can be Succeeded, Failed, orttttttttInProgress.

parameters.name: StatusMessage
parameters.description: The job status message.

parameters.name: Tier
parameters.description: The retrieval option to use for the archive retrieval.

parameters.name: VaultARN
parameters.description: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the vault of which the job is atttttttsubresource.

post.description: Initiate Job (POST jobs)This operation initiates a job of the specified type, which can be an archive retrieval or vault inventory retrieval.Initializing a Data Retrieval Job Retrieving an archive or a vault inventory are asynchronous operations that require you totttinitiate a job. Retrieval is a two-step process:tttInitiate a retrieval job.ImportantA data retrieval policy can cause your initiate retrieval job request to fail with attttttttPolicyEnforcedException exception. For more information about datatttttttretrieval policies, see Amazon Glacier Data Retrieval Policies. For more information about thettttttttPolicyEnforcedException exception, see Error Responses.After the job completes, download the bytes. ttThe retrieval request is executed asynchronously. When you initiate a retrieval job, Amazon Glacier creates a jobtttand returns a job ID in the response. When Amazon Glacier completes the job, you can get the job output (archive ortttinventory data). For information about getting job output, see the Get Job Output (GET output) operation. The job must complete before you can get its output. To determine when a job is complete, you have thetttfollowing options:tttUse an Amazon SNS notification— You can specify an Amazon Simple Notification Servicetttttt(Amazon SNS) topic to which Amazon Glacier can post a notification after the job is completed. You can specifyttttttan SNS topic per job request. The notification is sent only after Amazon Glacier completes the job. Inttttttaddition to specifying an SNS topic per job request, you can configure vault notifications for attttttvault so that job notifications are sent for all retrievals. For more information, see Set Vault Notification Configuration (PUTttnotification-configuration). Get job details— You can make a Describe Job (GET JobID) request to obtain jobttttttstatus information while a job is in progress. However, it is more efficient to use an Amazon SNSttttttnotification to determine when a job is complete.tttttNoteThe information you get via notification is same that you get by calling Describe Job (GET JobID). ttIf for a specific event, you add both the notification configuration on the vault and also specify an SNSttttopic in your initiate job request, Amazon Glacier sends both notifications. For more information, see Set Vault Notification Configuration (PUTttnotification-configuration).

parameters.name: ArchiveId
parameters.description: The ID of the archive that you want to retrieve. This field is required only ifttttttttType is set to archive-retrieval. An error occurs if youtttttttspecify this field for an inventory retrieval job request.

parameters.name: Description
parameters.description: The optional description for the job.

parameters.name: EndDate
parameters.description: The end of the date range in UTC for vault inventory retrieval that includes archivestttttttcreated before this date.

parameters.name: Format
parameters.description: When initiating a job to retrieve a vault inventory, you can optionally add this parametertttttttto your request to specify the output format. If you are initiating an inventory job and dotttttttnot specify a Format field, JSON is the default format.

parameters.name: Limit
parameters.description: The maximum number of inventory items returned per vault inventory retrievaltttttttrequest.

parameters.name: Marker
parameters.description: An opaque string that represents where to continue pagination of the vault inventorytttttttretrieval results. You use the marker in a new Initiate Job request to obtaintttttttadditional inventory items. If there are no more inventory items, this value is null.

parameters.name: RetrievalByteRange
parameters.description: The byte range to retrieve for an archive retrieval. in the formttttttttStartByteValue-EndByteValue Iftttttttnot specified, the whole archive is retrieved. If specified, the byte range must be megabytettttttt(1024*1024) aligned, which means that StartByteValue must be divisibletttttttby 1 MB, and the EndByteValue plus 1 must be divisible by 1 MB or betttttttthe end of the archive specified as the archive byte size value minus 1. IfttttttttRetrievalByteRange is not megabyte aligned, this operation returnsttttttta 400 response.

parameters.name: SNSTopic
parameters.description: The Amazon SNS topic ARN where Amazon Glacier sends a notification when the job is completed, and thetttttttoutput is ready for you to download. The specified topic publishes the notification to itstttttttsubscribers. The SNS topic must exist. If it does not, Amazon Glacier does not create it for you.tttttttAdditionally, the SNS topic must have a policy that allows the account that created the jobtttttttto publish messages to the topic. For information about SNS topic names, see CreateTopic in the AmazonttttttttSimple Notification ServicetttttttAPI Reference.

parameters.name: StartDate
parameters.description: The start of the date range in UTC for vault inventory retrieval that includes archivestttttttcreated on or after this date.

parameters.name: Tier
parameters.description: The retrieval option to use for the archive retrieval. Standard is thetttttttdefault value used.

parameters.name: Type
parameters.description: The job type. You can initiate a job to retrieve an archive or get an inventory of atttttttvault.

get.description: DescriptionThis operation returns information about a job you previously initiated, including the jobtttinitiation date, the user who initiated the job, the job status code/message and thetttAmazon Simple Notification Service (Amazon SNS) topic to notify after Amazon Glaciertttcompletes the job. For more information about initiating a job, see Initiate Job (POST jobs). tttNoteThis operation enables you to check the status of your job. However, it istttttstrongly recommended that you set up an Amazon SNS topic and specify it in yourtttttinitiate job request so that Amazon Glacier can notify the topic after it completestttttthe job. ttA job ID will not expire for at least 24 hours after Amazon Glacier completes the job. Requests

parameters.name: Action
parameters.description: The job type. It is either ArchiveRetrieval orttttttttInventoryRetrieval.

parameters.name: ArchiveId
parameters.description: For an ArchiveRetrieval job, this is the archive ID requested for download.tttttttOtherwise, this field is null.

parameters.name: ArchiveSHA256TreeHash
parameters.description: The SHA256 tree hash of the entire archive for an archive retrieval job. For inventorytttttttretrieval jobs, this field is null.

parameters.name: ArchiveSizeInBytes
parameters.description: For an ArchiveRetrieval job, this is the size in bytes of the archive beingtttttttrequested for download. For the InventoryRetrieval job, thetttttttvalue is null.

parameters.name: Completed
parameters.description: The job status. When a job is completed you get the jobs output using the Get Job Output (GET output).

parameters.name: CompletionDate
parameters.description: The UTC time that the job request completed. While the job is in progress, the valuetttttttwill be null.

parameters.name: CreationDate
parameters.description: The UTC time that the job was created.

parameters.name: EndDate
parameters.description: The end of the date range in UTC for vault inventory retrieval that includes tttttttarchives created before this date.

parameters.name: Format
parameters.description: The output format for the vault inventory list, which is set by the  tttttttInitiate Job (POST jobs) request  tttttttwhen initiating a job to retrieve a vault inventory.

parameters.name: InventorySizeInBytes
parameters.description: For an InventoryRetrieval job, this is the size in bytes of the inventorytttttttrequested for download. For the ArchiveRetrieval job, thetttttttvalue is null.

parameters.name: JobDescription
parameters.description: The job description you provided when you initiated the job.

parameters.name: JobId
parameters.description: The ID that represents the job in Amazon Glacier.

parameters.name: Limit
parameters.description: Specifies the maximum number of inventory items returned per vault inventory tttttttretrieval request. This limit is set when initiating the job with the a tttttttInitiate Job (POST jobs) request.

parameters.name: Marker
parameters.description: An opaque string that represents where to continue pagination of the vault inventorytttttttretrieval results. You use the marker in a new Initiate Job  request tttttttto obtain additional inventory items. If there aretttttttno more inventory items, this value is null. tttttttFor information about using the marker, see Range Inventory Retrieval.

parameters.name: RetrievalByteRange
parameters.description: The retrieved byte range for archive retrieval jobs in the formttttttttStartByteValue-EndByteValuetttttttIf you dont specify a range in the archive retrieval, then the wholetttttttarchive is retrieved; also StartByteValue equals 0,tttttttand EndByteValue equals the size of the archivetttttttminus 1. For inventory retrieval jobs, this field is null.

parameters.name: SHA256TreeHash
parameters.description: The SHA256 tree hash value for the requested range of an archive. If the Initiate Job (POST jobs) request for an archivetttttttspecified a tree-hash aligned range, then this field returns a value.tttttttFor more information about tree-hash alignment for archive rangetttttttretrievals, see Receiving Checksums When Downloading Data.

parameters.name: SNSTopic
parameters.description: An Amazon Simple Notification Service (Amazon SNS) topic that receivestttttttnotification.

parameters.name: StartDate
parameters.description: The start of the date range in UTC for vault inventory retrieval that includes archivestttttttcreated on or after this date.

parameters.name: StatusCode
parameters.description: The status code can be InProgress, Succeeded, orttttttttFailed, and indicates the status of the job.

parameters.name: StatusMessage
parameters.description: A friendly message that describes the job status.

parameters.name: Tier
parameters.description: The retrieval option to use for the archive retrieval.

parameters.name: VaultARN
parameters.description: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the vault from which the archivetttttttretrieval was requested.

get.description: DescriptionThis operation downloads the output of the job you initiated using Initiate Job (POST jobs). Dependingttton the job type you specified when you initiated the job, the output will be either thetttcontent of an archive or a vault inventory. You can download all the job output or download a portion of the output by specifyingttta byte range. For both archive and inventory retrieval jobs, you should verify the downloaded tttsize against the size returned in the headers from the tttGet Job Output response.For archive retrieval jobs, you should also verify that the size is what you expected. Iftttyou download a portion of the output, the expected size is based on the range of bytestttyou specified. For example, if you specify a range of bytes=0-1048575, you shouldtttverify your download size is 1,048,576 bytes. If you download an entire archive, thetttexpected size is the size of the archive when you uploaded it to Amazon Glacier.tttThe expected size is also returned in the headers from the tttGet Job Output response.In the case of an archive retrieval job, depending on the byte range youtttspecify, Amazon Glacier returns the checksum for the portion of the data. To ensure the portion you downloaded tttis the correct data, compute the checksum on the client, verify that the values match, tttand verify that the size is what you expected.A job ID does not expire for at least 24 hours after Amazon Glacier completes the job. Thattttis, you can download the job output within the 24-hour period after Amazon Glaciertttcompletes the job.Requests

parameters.name: ArchiveDescription
parameters.description: The description of an archive.

parameters.name: ArchiveId
parameters.description: The ID of an archive.

parameters.name: ArchiveList
parameters.description: An array of archive metadata. Each object in the array represents metadata for onetttttttarchive contained in the vault.

parameters.name: CreationDate
parameters.description: The UTC date and time the archive was created.

parameters.name: InventoryDate
parameters.description: The UTC date and time of the last inventory for the vault that was completed aftertttttttchanges to the vault. Even though Amazon Glacier prepares a vaulttttttttinventory once a day, the inventory date is only updated if there havetttttttbeen archive additions or deletions to the vault since the lasttttttttinventory.

parameters.name: SHA256TreeHash
parameters.description: The tree hash of the archive.

parameters.name: Size
parameters.description: The size in bytes of the archive.

parameters.name: VaultARN
parameters.description: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) resource from which the archivettttttttretrieval was requested.

delete.description: DescriptionThis operation aborts the vault locking process if the vault lock is not in thettttLocked state. If the vault lock is in the Locked statetttwhen this operation is requested, the operation returns anttttAccessDeniedException error. Aborting the vault locking process removestttthe vault lock policy from the specified vault. A vault lock is put into the InProgress state by calling Initiate Vault Lock (POST lock-policy). A vaulttttlock is put into the Locked state by calling Complete Vault Lock (POST lockId). You cantttget the state of a vault lock by calling Get Vault Lock (GET lock-policy). For more information about the vaulttttlocking process, see Amazon Glacier Vault Lock. For moretttinformation about vault lock policies, see Amazon Glacier Access Control with Vault Lock Policies.This operation is idempotent. You can successfully invoke this operation multiple times, iftttthe vault lock is in the InProgress state or if there is no policytttassociated with the vault.RequestsTo delete the vault lock policy, send an HTTP DELETE request to the URItttof the vaults lock-policy subresource.

get.description: DescriptionThis operation retrieves the following attributes from the lock-policytttsubresource set on the specified vault: tttThe vault lock policy set on the vault.The state of the vault lock, which is either InProgess ortttttttLocked.When the lock ID expires. The lock ID is used to complete the vault lockingttttttprocess.When the vault lock was initiated and put into the InProgress state.ttA vault lock is put into the InProgress state by calling Initiate Vault Lock (POST lock-policy). A vaulttttlock is put into the Locked state by calling Complete Vault Lock (POST lockId). You cantttabort the vault locking process by calling Abort Vault Lock (DELETE lock-policy). For more information about the vault lockingtttprocess, see Amazon Glacier Vault Lock.If there is no vault lock policy set on the vault, the operation returns a 404 Notttttfound error. For more information about vault lock policies, see Amazon Glacier Access Control with Vault Lock Policies.RequestsTo return the current vault lock policy and other attributes, send an HTTP GETtttrequest to the URI of the vaults lock-policy subresource as shown in thetttfollowing syntax example.

parameters.name: CreationDate
parameters.description: The UTC date and time at which the vault lock was put into the InProgresstttttttstate.

parameters.name: ExpirationDate
parameters.description: The UTC date and time at which the lock ID expires. This value can be nulltttttttif the vault lock is in a Locked state.

parameters.name: Policy
parameters.description: The vault lock policy as a JSON string, which uses \ as an escape character.

parameters.name: State
parameters.description: The state of the vault lock.

post.description: DescriptionThis operation initiates the vault locking process by doing the following: Installing a vault lock policy on the specified vault.Setting the lock state of vault lock to InProgress.Returning a lock ID, which is used to complete the vault locking process.tttttttYou can set one vault lock policy for each vault and this policy can be up to 20 KB in size.tttFor more information about vault lock policies, see Amazon Glacier Access Control with Vault Lock Policies.You must complete the vault locking process within 24 hours after the vault lock enters thettttInProgress state. After the 24 hour window ends, the lock ID expires,tttthe vault automatically exits the InProgress state, and the vault locktttpolicy is removed from the vault. You call Complete Vault Lock (POST lockId) to complete the vault locking process bytttsetting the state of the vault lock to Locked. NoteAfter a vault lock is in the Locked state, you cannot initiate a new vault lockttttfor the vault.You can abort the vault locking process by calling Abort Vault Lock (DELETE lock-policy). You can get the state of the vault lock bytttcalling Get Vault Lock (GET lock-policy). For moretttinformation about the vault locking process, see Amazon Glacier Vault Lock.If this operation is called when the vault lock is in the InProgress state, thetttoperation returns an AccessDeniedException error. When the vault lock is intttthe InProgress state you must call Abort Vault Lock (DELETE lock-policy) before you can initiate a new vault locktttpolicy. RequestsTo initiate the vault locking process, send an HTTP POST request to the URI oftttthe lock-policy subresource of the vault, as shown in the following syntaxtttexample.

parameters.name: Policy
parameters.description: The vault lock policy as a JSON string, which uses \ as an escapetttttttcharacter.

post.description: DescriptionThis operation completes the vault locking process by transitioning the vault lock from         the InProgress state to the Locked state, which causes the vault         lock policy to become unchangeable. A vault lock is put into the InProgress         state by calling Initiate Vault Lock (POST lock-policy). You can obtain the state of the vault lock by         calling Get Vault Lock (GET lock-policy). For more         information about the vault locking process, see Amazon Glacier Vault Lock. This operation is idempotent. This request is always successful if the vault lock is in the         Locked state and the provided lock ID matches the lock ID originally used to         lock the vault.If an invalid lock ID is passed in the request when the vault lock is in the Locked state,         the operation returns an AccessDeniedException error. If an invalid lock ID is         passed in the request when the vault lock is in the InProgress state, the operation throws an            InvalidParameter error.RequestsTo complete the vault locking process, send an HTTP POST request to the URI         of the vaults lock-policy subresource with a valid lock ID.

get.description: DescriptionThis multipart upload operation lists in-progress multipart uploads for the specified vault

parameters.name: ArchiveDescription
parameters.description: The description of the archive that was specified in the Initiate Multipart Uploadtttttttrequest. This field is null if no archive description wastttttttspecified in the Initiate Multipart Upload operation.

parameters.name: CreationDate
parameters.description: The UTC time that the multipart upload was initiated.

parameters.name: Marker
parameters.description: An opaque string that represents where to continue pagination of the results. You usetttttttthe marker in a new List Multipart Uploads request totttttttobtain more uploads in the list. If there are no more uploads, thistttttttvalue is null.

parameters.name: MultipartUploadId
parameters.description: The ID of the multipart upload.

parameters.name: PartSizeInBytes
parameters.description: The part size specified in the Initiate Multipart Upload (POSTttmultipart-uploads) request. This is thetttttttsize of all the parts in the upload except the last part, which may betttttttsmaller than this size.

parameters.name: UploadsList
parameters.description: A list of metadata about multipart upload objects. Each item in the list contains a settttttttof name-value pairs for the corresponding upload, includingttttttttArchiveDescription, CreationDate,ttttttttMultipartUploadId, PartSizeInBytes, andttttttttVaultARN.

parameters.name: VaultARN
parameters.description: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the vault that contains the archive.

delete.description: DescriptionThis multipart upload operation aborts a multipart upload identified by the uploadtttID

get.description: DescriptionThis multipart upload operation lists the parts of an archive that have been uploaded in atttspecific multipart upload identified by an upload ID

parameters.name: ArchiveDescription
parameters.description: The description of the archive that was specified in the Initiate Multipart Uploadtttttttrequest. This field is null if no archive description wastttttttspecified in the Initiate Multipart Upload operation.

parameters.name: CreationDate
parameters.description: The UTC time that the multipart upload was initiated.

parameters.name: Marker
parameters.description: An opaque string that represents where to continue pagination of the results. You usetttttttthe marker in a new List Parts request to obtain more jobstttttttin the list. If there are no more parts, this value istttttttnull.

parameters.name: MultipartUploadId
parameters.description: The ID of the upload to which the parts are associated.

parameters.name: Parts
parameters.description: A list of the part sizes of the multipart upload. Each object in the array contains attttttttRangeBytes and sha256-tree-hash name/valuetttttttpair.

parameters.name: PartSizeInBytes
parameters.description: The part size in bytes. This is the same value that you specified intttttttthe Initiate Multipart Upload request.

parameters.name: RangeInBytes
parameters.description: The byte range of a part, inclusive of the upper value of the range.

parameters.name: SHA256TreeHash
parameters.description: The SHA256 tree hash value that Amazon Glacier calculated for the part. This field is neverttttttttnull.

parameters.name: VaultARN
parameters.description: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the vault to which the multiparttttttttupload was initiated.

post.description: DescriptionYou call this multipart upload operation to inform Amazon Glacier that all the archive parts havetttbeen uploaded and Amazon Glacier can now assemble the archive from the uploaded parts

put.description: DescriptionThis multipart upload operation uploads a part of an archive

delete.description: DescriptionThis operation deletes the notification configuration set for a vault tttSet Vault Notification Configuration (PUTttnotification-configuration). The operation isttteventually consistent—that is, it might take some time for Amazon Glacier totttcompletely disable the notifications, and you might still receive some notifications forttta short time after you send the delete request. RequestsTo delete a vaults notification configuration, send a DELETE request to thetttvaults notification-configuration subresource.

get.description: DescriptionThis operation retrieves the notification-configuration subresource set on thetttvault (see Set Vault Notification Configuration (PUTttnotification-configuration). If notification configuration for atttvault is not set, the operation returns a 404 Not Found error. For moretttinformation about vault notifications, see Configuring Vault Notifications in Amazon Glacier. RequestsTo retrieve the notification configuration information, send a GET request totttthe URI of a vaults notification-configuration subresource.

parameters.name: Events
parameters.description: A list of one or more events for which Amazon Glacier will send a notification to thettttttttspecified Amazon SNS topic. For information about vault events forttttttttwhich you can configure a vault to publish notifications, see Set Vault Notification Configuration (PUTttnotification-configuration).

parameters.name: SNSTopic
parameters.description: The Amazon Simple Notification Service (Amazon SNS) topic Amazon Resource Name (ARN).ttttttttFor more information, see Getting Started with Amazon SNS in the Amazon Simple Notification Service Getting Started Guide.

put.description: DescriptionRetrieving an archive and a vault inventory are asynchronous operations in Amazon Glacier for whichtttyou must first initiate a job and wait for the job to complete before you can downloadtttthe job output. Most Amazon Glacier jobs take about four hours to complete. You can configure atttvault to post a message to an Amazon Simple Notification Service (Amazon SNS) topic when these jobs complete. You cantttuse this operation to set notification configuration on the vault. For more information,tttsee Configuring Vault Notifications in Amazon Glacier.tttttTo configure vault notifications, send a PUT request to thettttnotification-configuration subresource of the vault. A notificationtttconfiguration is specific to a vault; therefore, it is also referred to as a vaulttttsubresource. The request should include a JSON document that provides an Amazon Simple Notification Service (Amazon SNS) topic and the events for which you want Amazon Glacier totttsend notifications to the topic.You can configure a vault to publish a notification for the following vault events:tttArchiveRetrievalCompleted— This eventttttttoccurs when a job that was initiated for an archive retrieval is completedttttttt(Initiate Job (POST jobs)). The status of the completedttttttjob can be Succeeded or Failed. The notificationttttttsent to the SNS topic is the same output as returned from Describe Job (GET JobID).InventoryRetrievalCompleted— This eventttttttoccurs when a job that was initiated for an inventory retrieval is completedttttttt(Initiate Job (POST jobs)). The status of the completedttttttjob can be Succeeded or Failed. The notificationttttttsent to the SNS topic is the same output as returned from Describe Job (GET JobID).ttAmazon SNS topics must grant permission to the vault to be allowed to publish notificationstttto the topic.RequestsTo set notification configuration on your vault, send a PUT request to the URI of thetttvaults notification-configuration subresource. You specify thetttconfiguration in the request body. The configuration includes the Amazon SNS topic nametttand an array of events that trigger notification to each topic.

parameters.name: Events
parameters.description: An array of one or more events for which you want Amazon Glacier to sendtttttttnotification.

parameters.name: SNSTopic
parameters.description: The Amazon SNS topic ARN. For more information, go to Getting Started with Amazon SNS in the Amazon Simple Notification Service Getting Started Guide.

syntax.description: List Provisioned Capacity (GET        provisioned-capacity)This operation lists the provisioned capacity for the specified AWS account.        Request SyntaxTo list the provisioned retrieval capacity for an account, send an HTTP GET request            to the provisioned-capacity URI as shown in the following syntax example.GET /AccountId/provisioned-capacity HTTP/1.1Host: glacier.Region.amazonaws.comDate: DateAuthorization: SignatureValuex-amz-glacier-version: 2012-06-01              NoteThe AccountId value is the AWS account ID. This value must match the AWS account ID associated with the credentials used to sign the request. You can either specify an AWS account ID or optionally a single - (hyphen), in which case Amazon Glacier uses the AWS account ID associated with the credentials used to sign the request. If you specify your account ID, do not include any hyphens (-) in the ID.          Request ParametersThis operation does not use request parameters.Request HeadersThis operation uses only request headers that are common to all operations. For information about common request headers, see tCommon Request Headers.Request BodyThis operation does not have a request body.ResponsesIf the operation is successful, the service sends back an HTTP 200 OK response.

parameters.name: CapacityId
parameters.description: The ID that identifies the provisioned capacity unit.

parameters.name: DryRun
parameters.description: Checks whether you have the required permissions for the action, without actually making the request,        and provides an error response. If you have the required permissions, the error response is DryRunOperation.        Otherwise, it is UnauthorizedOperation.

parameters.name: ExpirationDate
parameters.description: The date that the provisioned capacity unit expires, in Coordinated                            Universal Time (UTC).

parameters.name: Filter.N
parameters.description: One or more filters.

parameters.name: NetworkInterfaceId.N
parameters.description: One or more network interface IDs.

parameters.name: StartDate
parameters.description: The date that the provisioned capacity unit was purchased, in Coordinated                            Universal Time (UTC).

parameters.name: TagKeys
parameters.description: A list of tag keys. Each corresponding tag is removed from the vault.

parameters.name: Tags
parameters.description: The tags attached to the vault. Each tag is composed of a key and a                        value.
